Field Label:
Febrile seizures
Seizure of any type (or unknown type) provoked
by a documented fever of >38째C/100.4째F

Aura (simple partial)
See ILAE definition

Focal dyscognitive (complex partial)
See ILAE definition

Bilateral convulsive
See ILAE definition, focal seizure evolving to a bilateral convulsion section

Focal other seizure types, please specify
Focal seizures that do not fit the criteria for an aura or focal dyscognitive seizure or are of unknown type. A focal clonic seizure with retained awareness can be included here.

Other seizure types, please specify
Seizures of unknown type or rare cases of generalised seizures

Field Label:
Drug resistant
Failure of adequate trials of two tolerated and appropriately chosen and used AED schedules (whether as monotherapies or in combination) to achieve sustained seizure freedom (see Kwan, P. et al, Epilepsia 2010)

Field Note: Family history of any seizures (including febrile) regardless of reported aetiology. Family history refers to any biological relative of the proband, including their offspring.

First-degree relative is defined as the proband's biological mother, father, brother, sister, son or daughter. The relative is regarded as 'affected' if they have any history of seizures (including febrile) regardless of reported aetiology.

Field Label: Details of family history of epilepsy
Field Note: Additional information about family history, other than that captured in the 'First degree relative affected?' section.

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels:
209, "Benign" Childhood Epilepsies: Childhood Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes [ILAE Definition] | 210, "Benign" Childhood Epilepsies: Atypical Childhood Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes [ILAE Definition] | 211, "Benign" Childhood Epilepsies: Benign Occipital Epilepsy (Panayiotopoulos) [ILAE Definition] | 212, "Benign" Childhood Epilepsies: Benign Occipital Epilepsy (Gastaut) [ILAE Definition] | 213, "Benign" Childhood Epilepsies: Idiopathic photosensitive occipital lobe epilepsy [ILAE Definition] | 220, Other Non-lesional Focal Epilepsies: Frontal
Non-lesional epilepsy with clinical and/or EEG evidence of a frontal localization [ILAE Definition]
| 221, Other Non-lesional Focal Epilepsies: Frontotemporal
Non-lesional epilepsy with clinical and/or EEG evidence of a frontotemporal localization.]
| 222, Other Non-lesional Focal Epilepsies: Temporal
Non-lesional epilepsy with clinical and/or EEG evidence of a temporal localization [ILAE Definition] that does not meet the criteria for Childhood Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes. Mesial temporal lobe epilepsy secondary to hippocampal sclerosis can be included here.
| 223, Other Non-lesional Focal Epilepsies: Occipital
Non-lesional epilepsy with clinical and/or EEG evidence of an occipital localization [ILAE Definition] that does not meet the criteria for any of the benign occipital epilepsy syndromes.
| 224, Other Non-lesional Focal Epilepsies: Temporoccipital
Non-lesional epilepsy with clinical and/or EEG evidence of a temporoccipital localization.
| 225, Other Non-lesional Focal Epilepsies: Parietal
Non lesional epilepsy with clinical and/or EEG evidence of a parietal localization [ILAE Definition]
| 226, Other Non-lesional Focal Epilepsies: Multifocal
Non-lesional epilepsy with clinical and/or EEG evidence of more than one localization. Please provide additional details in the Epilepsy Syndrome Comments section.
| 227, Other Non-lesional Focal Epilepsies: Unspecified
Non-lesional epilepsy with clinical and/or EEG evidence of focal onset but the specific localization is undetermined.
